titleStmt.title: Perhaps it is not alone
a hand-written transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This manuscript is a partial draft of "American National Literature. Is There Any Such Thing--or Can There Ever Be?," which first appeared in the March 1891 issue of North American Review under the title, "Have We a National Literature?" before appearing in Good-Bye My Fancy (1891) and Complete Prose Works (1892).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: These States and the Kosmical Scale
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839â€“1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.p: Perhaps, my friends, it is not onlyalone the free schools and newspapers—not only railroads, fa steam, or electricity—not our all the iron, whea cotton, pork, and petroleum or even the gold and silverandand a surplus of a hundred millions — more of our States—nor even the 14th and 15th Amendments—and a population of 50 or fiftysixty five millions and cash incalculable that can put These States highest or among the highest on the univers kosmical scale of History,—but perfect, cute and homely, moral Personalities—great literatures and efforts, Sociologicalnative something else is indispensable.
